page.title: 16FARMING - SOIL & CROPS
page.content: The soils and relief of the area are such that only a limited amount of any one type of farming can be done on each soil. On the top of the Downs the soil is fertile, with a clay base and a ph of 7.5. The clay traps the water making the land suitable for wheat, barley and rape. On the scarp slope of the Downs the soil on the chalk upland is very thin and dry supporting only sparse growth such as beech and yew trees. At the base of the chalk clay is found, which is saturated to various degrees according to the time of year. This lends itself to grazing and fodder crops. On the lower slopes of Boxley, where the soil is not saturated or acid, orchards of pear and apple are found.
